Revenue-Sharing based Computation-Resource Allocation for Mobile Blockchain
1
Revenue-Sharing based Computation-Resource
Allocation for Mobile Blockchain
Yuan Wu1, Xu Xu2, Liping Qian2, Bo Ji3, Zhiguo Shi4, Weijia Jia1
1 State Key Laboratory of Internet of Things for Smart City, University of Macau, Taipa, Macau, China
2 College of Information Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou, China
3 Department of Computer and Information Sciences, Temple University, Philadelphia, USA
4 College of Information Science and Electronic Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Abstract—In this paper, we investigate the revenue-sharing
based computation-resource allocation for mobile Blockchain, in
which conventional mobile devices (i.e., the edge-computing users,
EUs) can acquire computation-resources from the edge-server
(ES) for increasing their chances of winning the mining game in
Blockchain. Meanwhile, as a compensation to the ES, the EUs
adopt the revenue-sharing mechanism by sharing parts of their
respective rewards to the ES. We formulate a joint optimization of
the ES’s computation-resource allocation to the EUs and the EUs’
revenue-sharing to the ES, with the objective of maximizing the
system-reward of all EUs and the ES. Despite the non-convexity of
the joint optimization problem, we propose an algorithm based on
the cyclic block coordinate descent (CBCD) to solve the problem.
Our algorithm decouples the original problem into two subprob-
lems and alternatively optimizes the EUs’ revenue-sharing and
ES’s computation-resource allocation until reaching convergence.
For each subproblem, we also propose an efficient algorithm
for solving it. Numerical results are provided to validate the
effectiveness and efficiency of our proposed algorithms, as well
as the performance advantage of our proposed revenue-sharing
based computation-resource allocation for mobile Blockchain.
I. INTRODUCTION
Blockchain has been envisioned as a tamper-proof ledge
system for recording digital transactions in future Internet
without the involvement of centralized authorities [1]. Thanks
to its nature of decentralized management, Blokchain has been
widely exploited in different sections, e.g., finance, logistics,
and Internet of Things [2]–[5]. In many Blockchain enabled
services, users (i.e., which are also called as the miners) are
required to join a mining game for competitively solving the
proof-of-work puzzle. The winner of the mining game can
obtain the consequent reward (e.g., the Bitcoin or the right for
adding new data) after reaching consensus among all users.
However, the substantial amount of computation burdens for
solving proof-of-work puzzle is prohibitive from the perspec-
tive of conventional users (e.g., mobile terminals) which are
in general equipped with very limited computation-resources.
The advanced edge computing, which enables users to acquire

additional computation-resources from nearby edge-servers
(ESs) deployed at the edge of wireless networks, provides a
promising solution to address this issue [6]. Thanks to the
ES’s sufficient computation-resources, edge-computing users
(EUs) can effectively enhance their computation-capabilities
and thus increase the chance in winning the mining game.
Despite the potential of edge computing with its wide appli-
cations [7], a proper allocation of computation-resource and
communication-resource (for delivering the computation-task)
plays a vital role to the success of edge computing, which thus
has raised lots of research interests in recent years [8]–[14].
Recently, there have been several studies investigating the
exploitation of edge computing for Blockchain and the cor-
responding allocation of computation-resource for users to
enhance the computation-capability. In [15], the authors intro-
duced the concept of edge computing for mobile Blockchain
and an economic approach for computation-resource man-
agement. In [16], the authors further studied the interaction
between the cloud/fog providers and the miners in a proof-
of-work based Blockchain network by using the Stackelberg
game approach. In [17], an auction based approach has
been proposed for maximizing the social welfare of mobile
blockchain system. The authors of [18] considered the highly
dynamic environments and proposed a learning-based online
computation offloading approach for blockchain-empowered
mobile edge computing. The authors of [19] proposed a
coalition game based computation resource allocation scheme
for Blockchain networks. A hierarchical edge-cloud computing
paradigm for Blockchain mining game has been proposed in
[20]. In [21], a multi-hop cooperative computation offloading
algorithm has been proposed for both data processing tasks
and the mining tasks. In [22], [23], efficient Blockchain-based
MEC architecture for video delivery has been proposed.
Despite the above studies, it is still an open question
regarding how different EUs can properly share the ES’s
computation-resource, and moreover, how the ES and EUs can
jointly benefit from the MEC process. To this end, we adopt
the revenue-sharing mechanism [24], [25] and investigate the
revenue-sharing based edge computing for mobile Blockchain.
Our contributions in this work can be summarized as follows.
• To investigate the interaction between the ES and EUs, we
focus on a scenario in which a group of the EUs acquire
the computation-resources from the ES and further share
part of their respective rewards with the ES. We formulate

a joint optimization of the ES’s computation-resource
allocation to the EUs and the EUs’ revenue-sharing with
the ES, with the objective of maximizing the system-wise
utility of all EUs and the ES.
• Despite the non-convexity of the joint optimization prob-
lem, we propose an efficient algorithm which is based on
the cyclic block coordinate descent (CBCD) [28], [29] to
solve the problem. Our algorithm decouples the original
problem into two subproblems and alternatively optimizes
the EUs’ revenue-sharing and ES’s computation-resource
allocation until reaching convergence. For each subprob-
lem, we propose an efficient algorithm for solving it.
• We provide extensive numerical results to validate the
effectiveness and efficiency of our proposed algorithm-
s. The comparison with LINGO [26] shows that our
proposed algorithm can always achieve the close-to-
optimum solution for the original joint optimization prob-
lem and reduce the computation-time significantly. In
addition, the comparison with some heuristic offloading
scheme validates that our proposed revenue-sharing based
computation-resource allocation can increase the system-
wise performance for mobile Blockchain.
The remainder of this paper is as follows. We present the
system model and problem formulation in Section II. We
analyze the problem and propose an efficient algorithm for
solution in Section III. Numerical results are presented in
Section IV, and finally Section V concludes this work.

Fig. 1: System model considered in this work
Figure 1 illustrates the considered system model, in which a
group of EUs I = {1, 2, .., I} are competing with each other
in a single-pool mining process. To increase the chance of
being a winner, each EU can acquire additional computation-
resource from an ES. As an compensation for the ES, each
EU shares a portion of its reward in the mining process with
the ES. Specifically, for each EU i, we denote γi as EU i’s
revenue-sharing variable, namely, EU i keeps the portion of
γi of its reward while sharing (1−γi) of its reward to the ES.
Thanks to the edge computing, each EU i can obtain a total
amount of computation-resource as

In Problem (JRARS), we adopt the logarithmic utility function

simple form, Problem (JRARS) is very challenging to solve,
due to the non-convexity of the objective function. To address
this difficulty, we exploit the hidden convexity of Problem
(JRARS) (when part of the variables are fixed), with the details
illustrated in the next Section III. Then, we propose a CBCD-
based algorithm for solving Problem (JRARS).

Based on the above decomposition, we can identify the
following important feature.
Proposition 1: Given μ, Subproblem (CRAO-Sub) is a
strictly convex optimization problem with respect to {xi}∀i∈I .
Proof: Recall that given {γi}i∈I , parameters {Ai, Bi}i∈I
are all constants. Thus, the objective function of Subproblem
(CRAO-Sub) with given μ is strictly convex [27]. Therefore,
Subproblem (CRAO-Sub) is a convex optimization problem.
Proposition 1 indicates that Subproblem (CRAO-Sub) can
be efficiently solved (e.g., by using the interior point method).
In this work, we adopt CVX (i.e., a convex optimization
solver) to solve Subproblem (CRAO-Sub) [27], based on
which we can obtain the value of Vμ for each μ.
However, the difficulty in solving Top-problem (CRAO-
Top) lies in that we cannot express Vμ analytically. As a
result, Top-problem (CRAO-Top) is an optimization problem
without an analytical objective function. Fortunately, the fea-
sible region of μ is a fixed interval [0, C tot]. Therefore, we can
exploit the line-search with a sufficiently small step-size for
solving Top-problem (CRAO-Top). In particular, to reduce the
complexity of when we execute the line-search, we exploit the
following feature:
Proposition 2: A necessary condition for ensuring the fea-
sibility of Subproblem (CRAO-Sub) is as follows
μ ≥ max{C(μ)−∑i∈I(1− γi)Ai, 0}

Proposition 3: Given {xi}i∈I , Problem (RSO) is a strictly

Proof: The proof directly follows the convex optimization

solution of Problem (RSO). Specifically, let Ω denote the

IV. NUMERICAL RESULTS
We present the numerical results to validate our proposed
algorithms and the performance of our revenue-sharing based
computation offloading for mobile Blockchain. To this end,
we setup the scenario as follows. According to [16], we
set R=$7000, r=$20/Mbit, and λ= 1
600 . In addition, we set
p = $40/GHash and the ES’s computation-resource capacity
C tot=30GHash/sec.
Figures 3, 4, and 5 together show the convergence of
our proposed CBCD-based Algorithm to the solution of
Problem (JRARS). Specifically, we test two scenarios, i.e.,
the 3-EU case with {xloc
i }i∈I = {0.5, 1.5, 2.5} GHash/sec
and {ti}i∈I = {0.6, 0.8, 1.0} Mbits, and 4-EU case with

of the total system-wise utility when executing CBCD-
Algorithm. As a benchmark, we use the global-solver of
LINGO to solve Problem (JRARS) directly1 and obtain the
globally optimal solution for the purpose of comparison.
Figure 3 shows that our proposed algorithm can quickly
convergence to the optimal solution. Figure 4 shows the
convergence of all EUs’ revenue-sharing variables {γi}i∈I ,
and Figure 5 shows the convergence of all EUs’ achieved
rewards and the ES’s reward. In particular, it is reasonable
to observe from Figure 5 that all EUs and the ES obtain their
respective revenues in a fairness manner, since we adopt the
objective function function that accounts for the proportional
fairness in Problem (JRARS).

computation-resource allocation scheme, in which the ES
equally divides its total computation-resource to all EUs
(i.e., the equal-allocation, EA-scheme as shown in Figure

subplot and the 4-EU case in the right-subplot. For each

Fig. 8: Advantage of our proposed revenue-sharing based scheme
V. CONCLUSIONS
In this paper, we have studied the revenue-sharing based
computation-resource allocation in edge computing for mobile
Blockchain, in which EUs acquire additional computation-
resources from an ES to increase the chance in winning
the mining-game and further share parts of their respective
rewards to the ES as a compensation. To study this prob-
lem, we have formulated a joint optimization of the ES’s
computation-resource allocation and the EUs’ revenue-sharing
for maximizing the system-wise utility of all EUs and the ES.
Despite the non-convexity of the joint optimization problem,
we have exploited its hidden convexity via the framework
of CBCD and proposed an efficient algorithm to solve the
problem. Numerical results have been provided to validate the
effectiveness and efficiency of our proposed algorithm and
to demonstrate the advantage of the revenue-sharing based
computation-resource allocation. In our future work, we will
further investigate the scenario of multi-pool mining in which
users can flexibly join different pools for mining-competition.
